body.p:
My dear Sir! Agreeably to my promise,
I herewith forward you, the translation of a part of Dr M's
work, such as it has gone forth from my first scrawl,—
want of time, soreness of a finger of my right hand, and the
fear that a longer delay might cause it exclusion from the
July No. of the O., having prevented me to give the translation
a proper finish. I would request you, therefore, to lay your
correcting hand upon it, in a manner, as to make it worthy of
publication. Should you, however, not be wiling, to publish
the work at all, you would confer a great favor upon me,
by sending my H. I. back, as I have no other copy of my
translation. The part sent here, is about a third of
the whole work.

I embrace this opportunity, to make some
remarks on your letter of____(without date), which was handed
to me by J. N. Hart sen. Esq.

Well do I know, that it was not Religion,
which banished you form your ministerial office ,as little as
any Jewish Minister in America, has as yet been persecuted
from real religious motives of his persecutors. Private hatred,
jealousy, envy,and often mere will, called forth by wounded
pride, offended selfishness, in the boldness with which the
Minster “dared” to attack abuses, absurdities, sins &c, of
which some or another of his flock happened to have been guilty,
and, consequently, the fact, that felt the touch, were and still are

the motives of all those persecutions. The Jews still look up
on their Minister as their most obedient servant, and, as soon
as he has conjured up, by his independen stand, the displeasure
of but One of the mighty, a party is soon formed, and he
falls as their victim.

Before I was in the Ministry, I knew already, from
my own observations, that there was but little true Religion to be
found amongst our coreligionists, but that the want of religious
principles was carried to so great an extent, as to make
our holy Religion a mere burlesque, I learned already by my
own ministerial experiences of but one years' duration. People
model Religion, its forms and ceremonies, according to their own
task, fancy and, convenience and worldly interest, Hebrew
may be well said also of our days. Hebrew
Or is it not a farce, to see people thunder and work against
the abolishment of but a few offerings, who publicly violate their
Sabbath? To see people smoke their sigars on Sabbath, who
would curse the Reformers?! (My own ears have heard it); To
hear people boast of their strictly conforming with the traditional
laws, to demand the fulfilment of all rabbinical morning
precepts, and, with the same breath, require the sexton to
cut Hebrew only on one undergarment? Nay! Is it not
a humbug to hear a minister preach on the Divinity of the
oral law, who shaves, tho' that law tells him, that shaving
is a 5 fold prohibition!? to hear another publicly proclaim,
that an intermarriage with Reformers was worse than that with
Christians, who would not set his foot upon the Synagogue of
Reformers,—and—a few months afterwards, his daughter is
married to a Reformer of the worst kind, whom true Reformers

would even disclaim as one of theirs, and whose family is even
intermarried with Christians,—to hear ministers call themselves
adherents to the old orthodox school, who would ride on Hebrew?!
Oh! it is heart-rending, to hear & see all these things, and to
know, that all our labors are in vain! For, I must confess, that
this is my innermost belief, and that do not see any result
to be produced by your proposed Union-Meeting. But do
not conclude from this remark, that I would refuse my co-
operations, I also understand the call Hebrew
Hebrew. But I have my doubts, suspicions and fears. I do
not see any possibility for a reconciliation of the different parties
in the meeting. Where is the rallying point, in which for instance
Drs Wise and Raphall could meet? Or could you expect from
me to give up the organ, or to reinstate the second day of our
festivals, if it should happen, that a majority was against
my & my congregations principles?_ Or would Rev. Isaacs
or yourself submit, if it happened that the Reformers had the
ascendency?! Moreover, I cannot think, that all our colleagues,
would be independent enough, precarious as their offices are,
to utter their full and true opinions,—the same policy, that
actuates them on their pulpits, will guide them also at the Meeting.
But suppose even, we all could agree on some points, what power
have we, to execute our resolutions? Are not our congregations
sovereign, and do you think, that even a unanimity as the Meeting
would at once dispel all party spirit from them? Will they
because we have spoken on the sanctity of the sabbath &c &c, call
their sons back from the Colleges, where they can not keep it,—
will they call their sons back from California, and all other
places, where there are no Jews, and where they therefore cannot

conform with even the Biblical laws, to say nothing of the Rabbinical
?—will all, at once, shut their stores on Sabbath, and give
up their offices, which compell them to violate it?! These and other
considerations which I could multiply at infinitum, fill me with serious
doubts as to any salutory result, to be derived from a meeting.
Since, as I never fear, to meet my antagonists, I would have the
announcement of the Meeting, hoping for one good ?;—that we
ministers, of all colors, may learn to know and to respect each other
seeing that all of us, are actuated by honest motives, in our re-
spective teachings,—a result which, I trust, would beneficially
also reflect upon our flocks.—

But let me here suggest a practical point, with regard to
the Meeting. Should not the Ministers, now residing in NYork, say
Drs Lilienthal, Merzbacher, Raphael & Mr Isaacs,—being the represent-
atives of all parties, at the same time,—at once unite for, and
immediately issue a proclamation?! Perhaps their call would be
responded to from all parts of the U. S. What do think of this
prop suggestion. I have other practical suggestions in store,
e.g. With regard to expenses &c., but do now withhold them, until
I have heard other colleagues, who are older, than I am.

With regard to your complaint, about the paucity of your subscribers,
and the illiberality of some Reformers, I beg leave to remark: It is indeed
not illiberality on their part, when they do not read your periodical, but
their principle tells them so. Why should they ? the rod, with which they are
lashed? They are men of principles—for as soon, as the Asmonean un-
furled the banner of Reform, a great many Reformers became its subscribers;
it has at least 25 in my congr. alone,—and I can promise you a
greater number yet, if you do, what the ? did. Mr Poznanski alone will
subscribe for 3 copies. Are the Reformers not more grateful to their ad-
vocate than the Orthodox. I have often heard, that there were more Orthodox
than Reformers, and yet, the Orthodox allow their most talented champions
“to starve?” If the Orthodox do not patronise their paper, should the Re-
formers do it, in their stead!? And besides, have not many orthodox also
discontinued the A, as soon as Dr W. became co-editor. (I. Asm. Of 22 Oct. 52).
How many subscribers have you in Rev. Jacobs orthodox congr. that numbers about
80-90 members, mine numbers 40-50 and 25 are subscribers of the A.
Please calculate the ratio—and the balance the liberality of both parties.
